column2: I-Vt.
column3: is asking colleagues to support overriding the Yemen resolution veto. (Sarah Silbiger/CQ Roll Call file photo) President Donald Trump’s veto of a joint resolution to put an end to U.S. support for the Saudi-led war in Yemen is going to kick the matter back to senators when they return to the Capitol next week. With recess continuing this week
column4: senators are in their home states
column5: on congressional delegations abroad and on the presidential campaign trail. But Vermont independent Sen. Bernie Sanders
column6: one of the many Democratic presidential candidates
column7: took a moment Monday to circulate a dear colleague letter seeking support for overriding the Trump veto. “For far too long Congress
column8: under both Democratic and Republican administrations
column9: has abdicated its Constitutional role with regard to the authorization of war
column10: ” Sanders wrote to his Senate colleagues. “The historic passage of this resolution
column11: the first time since the 1973 War Powers Resolution was passed that it has been successfully used to withdraw the United States from an unauthorized war
column12: was a long overdue step by Congress to reassert that authority.” “The Congress must now act to protect that constitutional responsibility by overriding the president’s veto
column13: ” Sanders wrote. Sanders
column14: who has been out on the presidential campaign trail himself
column15: wrote in the letter that supporters of the American involvement in Saudi Arabia’s Yemen campaign should seek a floor debate and and vote on that effort. The resolution gained significant momentum last year in the aftermath of the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul
column16: Turkey. ICYMI: Trump Suggests ‘Rogue Killers’ Could Be Responsible for Saudi Journalist's Death The Senate is likely going to have to take up the veto override vote
column17: though given that the underlying resolution only passed with a 54-46 vote under an expedited process
column18: it its not expected to prevail. There are a number of procedural options available to senators for dispensing with veto messages. Motions to refer the president’s message to committee or to table the matter entirely are possible (though unlikely to work given the support of a majority of senators for the resolution itself). While it’s unusual to try to force a cloture vote on a veto override effort
column19: it would be possible to debate the Yemen resolution to death since the 60 votes needed for cloture is a greater number than the number of senators supporting the joint resolution. The most straightforward way to dispense with the Yemen resolution would be to reach a unanimous consent agreement to set up a direct vote on overriding the Trump veto
column20: which would require 67 votes if all of the senators are in attendance that day. The president’s message
column21: which was released oh April 16
column22: contends that the War Powers resolution is not necessary since U.S. troops are not directly engaged in Yemen except for possible counter-terrorism operations. Trump’s message also said that the proposed restrictions would would be dangerous and counterproductive to foreign policy. “The Congress should not seek to prohibit certain tactical operations
column23: such as in-flight refueling
column24: or require military engagements to adhere to arbitrary timelines
column25: ” the message said. “Doing so would interfere with the President’s constitutional authority as Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces
column26: and could endanger our service members by impairing their ability to efficiently and effectively conduct military engagements and to withdraw in an orderly manner at the appropriate time.” Regardless
column27: the Democratic-led House of Representatives in not expected to ever get a chance to see the veto message
column28: since it’s on a joint resolution that was first introduced in the Senate. Get breaking news alerts and more from Roll Call on your iPhone or your Android. THE SOURCE FOR NEWS ON CAPITOL HILL SINCE 1955 Want insight more often?  Get Roll Call in your inbox  ×

column1: ---split---2.0---split---https://www.wired.com/story/my-search-for-boyhood-friend-led-to-dark-discovery/---split---Includes: Some writers used to drink when the words didn't come. Now we have the internet. Whenever I get stuck writing
column2: instead of sliding open the bottom drawer with the whiskey bottle
column3: I load up The New York Times or Politico
column4: check my email
column6: when all else fails
column7: start Googling old acquaintances. Most of us have done it. What ever happened to that bucktoothed kid from third grade? There he is
column8: grinning at you from the computer screen—balding
column9: paunchy
column10: mustachioed—and you're reading about his lake cottage
column11: his wood-turning hobby
column12: his Danube cruise
column13: his grandchildren
column14: his cats. A few months ago
column15: as I was staring at a wretched chapter I was trying to write
column16: I idly Googled the name “Peter Anderson” and “New Jersey.” Petey was my best friend growing up in Wellesley
column17: Massachusetts
column18: until he moved to New Jersey in seventh grade. But his was a common name
column19: and it returned tens of thousands of hits. Slumped in my chair
column20: continuing to waste time
column21: I tried his mother's name
column22: his father's
column23: and his brother's. There were just too many Andersons
column24: though
column25: and nothing of note surfaced
column26: beyond an old article in The Times of Trenton about a murder. This obviously wasn't my friend Petey: Dozens of other Peter Andersons in New Jersey were probably alive and well and going about their business. Petey lived across the brook from me in a white stucco house overlooking a golf course owned by Wellesley College. He was a droll kid with pale orange hair and papery skin through which you could see blue veins. He had a cheerful mother and a silent
column27: raddle-faced alcoholic father. After work
column28: his father parked himself in a wing chair in the living room
column29: shook out the afternoon Boston Herald
column30: and read it while gripping a scotch on the rocks. When he wanted another
column31: he jiggled the empty glass and Mrs. Anderson hurried in with fresh ice and the bottle. In those days before the curated childhood
column33: concerning ourselves with knocking on doors and running away
column34: getting chased off the golf course by greenskeepers
column37: and hunting for buried treasure. We dug holes in the woods behind the golf course
column38: hoping to unearth a sack of pine tree shillings from colonial days or gold doubloons from the time when Captain Kidd (so we fantasized) sailed his ship up the Charles River. One Young Boy's Magnificent Obsession With Fans A Deadly Hunt for Hidden Treasure Spawns an Online Mystery The Curse of the Bahia Emerald
column39: a Giant Green Rock That Ruins Lives One fall day
column40: my mother gave me an empty cookie tin with a picture of a great ship plowing through waves
column41: surrounded by gulls. Petey came over
column43: “Let's fill this with treasure and bury it.” We decided to leave it in the ground for 10 years and dig it up when we were 18. The year was 1964. Petey and I spent hours debating what to put in the tin. The treasure had to be something valuable enough that our grown-up selves would be glad to have it back. We gathered our best things and laid them out on my bed for inspection. Most of them struck us as childish junk
column44: but a few stood out as objects with adult gravitas. I chose a Morgan silver dollar
column46: and my finest arrowhead—an ancient beauty flaked out of petrified wood in which you could still see the tree rings. Among Petey's treasures were a squirrel skull
column47: a miniature brass cannon from the USS Constitution's gift shop
column48: and an intricate blob of lead he had made by melting fishing sinkers on the stove and pouring the molten metal into water. It was a method of telling the future
column49: he said. The blob predicted that his life would be one of wealth
column51: and happiness. As we looked over our carefully assembled treasures
column52: they still didn't seem adequate for a great journey into the future. I had an idea: Why not each write the story of our lives? Whatever else we put in the tin
column53: we knew this would make for good reading
column54: especially if we'd forgotten our childhoods
column55: like most adults we knew. Every afternoon for several weeks
column56: we gathered in Petey's living room and labored over legal pads
column57: sharpening and resharpening our pencils until the flakes lay in tiny curls all around us on the carpet. I called my opus “The Story of My Life So Far.” I remember writing about riding horses in Wyoming and living with a Luo family in the African bush
column58: eating ram guts and ugali for supper and listening to the lions roar at night. (I had eccentric parents.) Petey called his “Eight Years Old and Full of Beans
column59: ” a title I criticized as corny
column60: but he stuck with it. I didn't read his story and he didn't read mine; that would happen 10 years hence. When we were done
column63: and sealed them with wax. We carefully packed the tin
column64: then wrapped it in layers and layers of duct tape so it would be waterproof. I wondered: When we dug it up
column65: who would we be? What would America look like? Would there be flying cars and men on the moon? Would we all be Reds
column66: as my teacher said was going to happen if people didn't wake up? Would the world be a cinder from nuclear war? The future was strange
column68: and thrilling to ponder. The crucial question arose as to where to bury the tin. It had to be a far-off place where anyone could find it; that was part of the excitement. We settled on an abandoned field deep in the woods at the farthest edge of the Wellesley College property. One fine fall day
column72: Petey and I headed out. The maples had turned scarlet
column75: glowed like church glass against a blue sky. Once at the field
column76: we put down the shovel and pick and scoped out the scene. We decided on a hollow oak as our starting point. Standing at the foot of the oak
column77: I sighted into the field with my compass. Due west
column78: in the middle of the field
column79: stood a cedar sapling. We paced the distance through weeds and grass
column80: picking the cockleburs off our socks: 21 paces. Having established that distance
column81: we then measured nine paces due north. I sank the shovel into the ground and cut a rectangle in the tough grass. We worked off the turf in a single piece and laid it aside. Wielding the pick
column82: I broke up the dirt while Petey shoveled it out
column83: piling it nearby. In 20 minutes we had prepared a most excellent hole
column85: which cut through the upper layer of loam into a stratum of orange clay. We placed the tin inside and snugged it down tight. Petey backfilled the hole and smacked down the dirt with the back of the shovel. We replanted the grass on top
column86: brushed it out with our fingers
column87: and threw the remaining clods of dirt into the woods. A dozen artfully placed autumn leaves completed the picture. Up to that point in my life
column88: time had given me everything I had; I was now starting to realize it also took things away. We shook hands and promised to come back in 10 years. I drew a treasure map showing the oak tree
column91: with dotted lines indicating the number of paces and directions
column92: leading to where an X marked the spot. I made a copy of the map for Petey and locked mine in a tin safe hidden behind a secret panel in my room. There it remained as the years rolled by. In seventh grade
column93: Petey moved away to New Jersey. We were both devastated by the separation. We wrote long letters to each other
column94: some so fat they had to be rolled up and mailed in a tube. But over the course of a year
column95: the letters lost weight and became sickly
column96: and finally our friendship passed away peacefully in its sleep. The treasure was almost—but not quite—forgotten. When I was 16
column97: while rummaging through some old stuff
column98: I found the map still hidden in the safe. I stared at it
column99: thinking of my long-lost pal. We had promised to wait until 1974
column100: but I hadn't seen Petey in years
column101: and it felt like an eternity had passed since we buried the tin. The years between 8 and 16 are mighty indeed. Since Petey had left
column102: I figured the promises we had made to each other were no longer valid
column103: and I would be justified in digging up the box by myself
column104: two years before its time. I got a shovel out of the garage and
column106: set off. My days of roaming the woods were over
column107: but I still knew the land by heart. When I reached the location of the field
column109: I was shocked to discover it no longer existed. It had rejoined the forest
column110: growing into a thicket of red cedars
column112: and birches. I found the hollow oak. But when I stood at its base and trained my compass west
column113: I couldn't identify the cedar tree. There were dozens of cedars of varying sizes
column115: clustered in a dense stand. I measured out 21 paces
column116: trying to approximate the length of an 8-year-old's stride. Pushing through the branches
column117: I arrived at a tree that
column118: because it seemed to be the biggest
column119: might have been the one we used as a landmark. From there
column123: and began to dig. It was hard going
column124: hacking through mats of crisscrossing roots. After a while I hit softer dirt and the digging got easier. Down
column127: finding nothing. I paced it off again and dug another hole. Nothing. I dug a third
column128: then a fourth. Resentment mingled with a keen sense of loss. Up to that point in my life
column129: time had given me everything I had; I was now starting to realize it also took things away. The Preston family in 1963
column130: with the author in the center. Over the years
column131: thoughts of Petey drifted through my mind at random moments. An old friend said he'd heard Petey was cleaning swimming pools somewhere
column133: but I didn't get around to digging deeper. That's where things would have remained
column134: but for the constant temptation of the internet. Now
column137: trying to find out what someone I knew more than half a century ago was up to
column138: and having no success. And then I remembered a crucial detail: Petey's middle name was Stark. This was enough to refine the search—and up popped that same article in The Times of Trenton. On May 2
column141: the body of a Peter Anderson was found in a boarding house in Ewing
column142: New Jersey. The man's hands and feet were bound with packing tape. He had apparently been bludgeoned to death with a hammer. Curiously
column143: Petey's middle name appeared nowhere in the article. It seemed that the search engine had turned over an arbitrary stone. Still
column144: I was deeply troubled. I couldn't seem to verify that the murder victim wasn't Petey. Realizing I wasn't going to get any work done until I knew for sure
column145: I spent $9.95 on an Intelius search of public records. It revealed that Peter Stark Anderson
column146: son of Virginia and Perry Anderson
column150: and that the date of his death was May 2
column151: 2011. The murder victim was my friend Petey. I felt as though I had been suddenly poisoned; my insides seized up. Gripped by a feeling of nausea
column152: I began reading the other stories about the homicide
column153: of which there were half a dozen. The police had quickly identified a suspect
column154: a man named Robert Horrocks Jr.
column155: who had been working as a handyman at the boarding house where Petey lived. Horrocks had fled to Connecticut the night of the killing. His blood-stained clothes were recovered
column156: and he was brought back to New Jersey and charged with murder. At his bail reduction hearing
column158: his attorney contended that Horrocks had killed Petey while defending himself in a fight. Horrocks interrupted him and insisted on speaking. The judge
column160: warned him of his rights. Horrocks then said
column161: “I know I'm guilty of the crime.” At his sentencing
column162: Horrocks went on to tell the court why he was justified in killing Petey. While doing repairs at the boarding house
column164: he had brought along his girlfriend's autistic adult son
column165: whom Petey had sexually assaulted. I forced myself to read on
column166: stupefied with disbelief. Horrocks returned weeks later to take revenge. “I did what I had to do
column167: ” he reportedly said. “I didn't mean to kill the guy
column168: but he ended up dying and I'm paying for it. End of story.” According to The Times
column169: the prosecutor questioned Horrocks' account. Nobody
column171: could corroborate his story of a sexual assault
column172: including the autistic man himself. Furthermore
column174: Horrocks knew the son had been molested years before by another man. “The story was out there ripe for the picking
column175: and I suspect the defendant latched onto it as a justification
column176: ” she said. Horrocks was sentenced to 30 years in prison without possibility of parole. The story left my mind in a state of complete disorder. As a boy
column177: Petey had been terrified of violence. Being frail and gentle
column178: he was the target of bullying—shoulder bumping (ex-cuse me!)
column182: ” and smacking upside the head. He fled from any hint of conflict
column183: usually with a wiseass comment flung over his shoulder
column184: and he could outrun any goofus who took up the chase. I couldn't begin to fathom the trajectory that brought him from an upper-upper-middle-class home in Wellesley to a cramped boarding house in New Jersey. Details of his life came flickering back into my memory: Petey singing songs to his hamster Gertrude; Petey cradling his dying dog after she'd been hit by a car
column185: even though she was bleeding and peeing all over him; Petey writing silly stories about a magical valley where the animals talked like people; Petey and I burying a treasure. My feckless Googling had reaped a monstrous reality that I knew was going to haunt me for the rest of my life. I asked myself: Is there something righteous in facing reality
column186: or would it have been better to stay ignorant? A surfeit of ugly knowledge is a feature of our age
column187: a result of the internet carrying to our doorstep
column188: like a tomcat with a dead rat
column189: all manner of brutal information. How many others have flippantly Googled an old friend and discovered something ghastly? This was not knowledge as power; it was knowledge as sorrow. But I was not done. I had to know what happened. I started digging again. I got contact information for the prosecutor
column192: and the journalist who wrote The Times stories. I got the telephone number
column194: and email address of Petey's brother
column195: living in Massachusetts. I lined up all that information
column197: and squared it off on the corner of my desk. It was everything I needed to find the answer. I stared at it for weeks—and then I threw it out. In a world verminous with information
column198: there are some things I just don't want to know. A month or two later
column199: when I had at least minimally processed Petey's murder
column200: I did undertake one final bit of research. Using Google Earth
column201: I looked at the abandoned field where we buried the treasure. It had grown into solid forest—wild
column204: a small wilderness in suburbia. After 55 years
column205: the tin containing Petey's life story
column207: and a lying lump of lead is still there

---split---4.0---split---https://www.huffpost.com/highline/article/parkland/---split---Max Eden didn’t even want to read about Parkland. He saw the news on Valentine’s Day, after a dinner date with his girlfriend at a little French place in Washington, D.C., taking an Uber home. There was the gut-punch—“oh shit, another school shooting”—then the queasy afterthought that none of this hits as hard as it used to. He knew what would follow. For a few angry weeks, Democrats would demand gun control and Republicans would call for arming teachers. He decided he’d sit it out this time, ignore the news as much as possible. And for a few days he did, until a journalist tweeted that the shooter’s school record proved a point that Eden had been making for much of his career. At 30 years old, Eden has a neat beard, a balding head that he’s resigned himself to buzzing short and a quick, sometimes nervous intelligence. A Yale graduate, he is a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative think tank that focuses on economic and urban policy issues. For years, the institute has produced arguments about how liberal policies intended to help minorities actually hurt them. It underwrote the early welfare reform work of contrarian sociologist Charles Murray, whose book, “The Bell Curve,” infamously argued that there are racial differences in intelligence. Its senior fellow George Kelling helped advance the theory of “broken windows” policing, which posits that crackdowns on petty quality-of-life offenses ultimately reduce major crimes. More recently, fellow Heather Mac Donald has regularly appeared on Fox News to discuss the “Ferguson effect”—her argument that the Black Lives Matter movement has caused police to become less proactive, fueling urban crime. Eden’s portfolio was lower-profile. His speciality was education, which in conservative policy circles usually meant critiquing liberal reforms for focusing on underprivileged children at the expense of their more fortunate peers. (In 2016, he wrote an article to this effect titled “#AllKidsMatter.”) Eden’s mother had been a public school teacher in Cleveland, and her complaints made the work personal. For more stories that stay with you, subscribe to our newsletter. Over the previous two years, Eden had focused on school discipline. The Obama administration had embarked on a major effort to address the “school-to-prison pipeline”—the glaring racial disparity in school suspensions and expulsions, which is a major contributor to an even more glaring racial disparity in America’s prisons. Eden believed the reforms had plunged schools like his mother’s into chaos and saw the reformers themselves as members of a “social justice industrial complex.” “As more money flows to ‘woke’ conferences and training programs,” he would write, “school district leaders have increasingly learned that the fastest path to career advancement is to produce fake statistical progress for minority students while passionately decrying privilege and institutional racism.” Eden tracked the news for violent incidents—like a 2017 high school stabbing in the Bronx—at schools that had adopted the new approach. Still, compared to other education debates that riled up conservatives, such as campus sexual assault or bathroom access for transgender students, discipline reform never really caught on. There was, Eden said, no natural Republican “political constituency” for his issue. Until a few days after Parkland, when the journalist’s tweet started him thinking. The shooting had occurred at the most elite public school in one of the most affluent suburbs in Broward County, and Eden typically focused on low-income, urban, majority-minority schools. But then he noticed what kids from Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School were saying about Nikolas Cruz, the 19-year-old former MSD student charged with killing 17 students and staff and injuring 17 more. In TV interviews and on social media, the students insisted they’d repeatedly warned local authorities that Cruz was obsessed with guns. A couple of days after the massacre, the FBI acknowledged it had failed to act on two tips. It would emerge that Cruz had repeated interactions with the Broward County Sheriff’s Office as well. Eden wondered, he told me, whether the shooting was connected to Broward’s reputation as “ground zero” for a policy he characterized as “try to arrest as few students as possible.” In 2013, Broward had launched an arrest- and suspension-diversion program called PROMISE that became a national model for reformers. Many believed it had even helped inspire the Obama administration’s own efforts. And when Eden tangled with reform advocates online, asking them to show him where the new policies were working, they always pointed to Broward. In the days after the shooting, Parkland students led the country in the most forceful call for gun reform in recent memory, and plenty of conservatives were looking to place the blame on anything other than lax gun laws. The first to land on PROMISE was Jack Cashill, the conspiracy-minded author of a book about “the railroading of George Zimmerman.” Cashill had long argued that Trayvon Martin, the black teenager whom Zimmerman shot and killed in 2012, was in fact a budding criminal whose aptitude for “street fighting, drugs, guns, burglary and mixed martial arts” had been obscured because his Florida school district participated in a program to reduce student arrests. Now, Cashill theorized that Broward had similarly excused Cruz because, although he is white, his name made him “a statistical Hispanic.” The next day, a right-wing blog posted a series of tweets arguing that Cruz had benefited from “the Trayvon Martin standard.” The thread was shared almost 12,000 times, and the theory quickly spread from Infowars to Rush Limbaugh to Breitbart to Fox News, until Ann Coulter was describing PROMISE as “the school to mass murder pipeline.” But it was Eden, whose work had been cited in the Senate, who made the argument influential. ( 1 ) CNN’s Jake Tapper also aggressively questioned Broward Sheriff Scott Israel about the potential role of the district's discipline policies. That exchange was overshadowed by Israel's claim that he provided “amazing leadership, although the only armed official stationed at MSD failed to intervene in the massacre. Twelve days after the shooting

Runcie’s supporters expressed condolences to the grieving families but said their side of town hadn’t been represented in the debates over the last year. The vice mayor of West Park condemned “people who are pimping the pain of the victims” for political or personal vendettas. A state senator who represents parts of eastern Broward declared
column750: “Just as strongly as you feel about getting rid of Bob Runcie
column751: we feel just as strong that it ain’t going to happen.” Fred Guttenberg spoke
column752: wearing a shirt bearing Jaime's name and evidently distressed. “The bullet that shot my daughter did not know what color she was
column754: jabbing his finger in the air. “And I’m frustrated as hell at what’s happening in this room tonight to make this about color and socioeconomic status.” But for many of the black attendees at the town hall
column755: the attacks on PROMISE had always been about color. After the meeting
column756: online Runcie critics wrote that “the ‘bused’ people” had “taken over” the meeting and left no room for “legitimately concerned parents.” Pollack tweeted that Runcie was “trying to spark racial conflict” in “a demented effort to save his job.” After a school board meeting the next day
column757: Lori Alhadeff called for a vote on whether to fire Runcie for “willful neglect of duty.” The vote took place on March 5. Hundreds of people spilled into the halls and two overflow rooms. Over more than four hours
column758: five people spoke in favor of Runcie’s termination
column759: including one victim’s father. Eighty spoke in his defense
column762: clergy and two black mothers of MSD survivors. Many emphasized that Parkland was not the only community that had lost
column764: its children. “We grieved for you in a way that you’ll never understand
column765: ” said one man with a soft Caribbean accent. “It ripped our hearts open.” Others spoke of the need to move on. Runcie’s wife
column767: spoke last. She recalled her husband coming home the night of the shooting
column770: “I can’t believe I lost my babies.” Alhadeff’s motion lost
column771: 6-3. Runcie would stay. He told me that he hoped the district could harness all that passion from the meetings to find a way forward. To him
column772: the fight over PROMISE had raised “a big philosophical question [about] what we mature into as a society
column774: how we develop human beings. Do we recognize that all our fates are connected together? That what happens to you ultimately is somehow going to impact me?” But a year after the shooting
column775: not all shared such an optimistic view. Parents who’d become close in the immediate aftermath of the shooting had become estranged over political differences; the county seemed more polarized than ever before. At that final town hall
column776: Fred Guttenberg took stock of the situation with a muted
column778: and this community is coming apart.”

column1: ---split---4.0---split---https://www.wired.com/story/like-guns-social-media-is-weapon-should-be-regulated/---split---Includes: The decision by the Sri Lankan government this week to shut down the big social networks—including Facebook
column2: WhatsApp
column3: YouTube
column4: and Snapchat—in the aftermath of an Easter day terrorist attack on three Catholic churches and three upscale hotels feels like a turning point in our relationship with these platforms. A Gordian knot moment
column6: where instead of agonizing over how to untangle the social media mess you just pull out a sword and cut. The coordinated attacks
column7: which took place in three Sri Lankan cities and killed more than 300 people
column8: were designed to foment religious strife in a country that has been slowly recovering from a quarter-century-long civil war. On the 10-year path to peace and stability
column9: there have been occasional flareups of religious violence
column10: such as the anti-Muslim riots in March 2018 that left two people dead. In that case
column11: too
column12: the Sri Lankan government temporarily blocked the social networks to contain the violence’s spread. One member of parliament wrote on Twitter at the time
column13: “Hate speech on @facebook is increasing beyond acceptable levels #SriLanka. Government will have to act immediately to save lives.” He later amended his comment: “I didn’t mean that way. My bad. NO hate speech is acceptable. I meant discussions were beyond acceptable levels at this tense situation.” We get his point
column14: however
column15: even if it appeared insensitive: Facebook clearly doesn’t care enough about the lies and hatred on its site
column16: and usually that is appalling but survivable. At certain times
column17: however
column18: this negligence is more than appalling
column19: it is life-threatening. Noam Cohen is a journalist and author of The Know-It-Alls: The Rise of Silicon Valley as a Political Powerhouse and Social Wrecking Ball
column20: which uses the history of computer science and Stanford University to understand the libertarian ideas promoted by tech leaders. While working for The New York Times
column21: Cohen wrote some of the earliest articles about Wikipedia
column22: bitcoin
column23: Wikileaks
column24: and Twitter. He lives with his family in Brooklyn. The Easter attacks were of a different scale
column25: and the swift decision by the government to act against the social networks placed them in a different category—that is
column26: the authorities were essentially saying that the social networks are no longer considered tools that can be abused by bad actors to exacerbate tensions but weapons that must be removed from terrorists immediately. That same member of parliament felt no need to explain the blackout on Twitter this time. An aide to Sri Lanka’s president was quoted in The New York Times saying “this was a unilateral decision.” Before our eyes
column27: the world is reassessing the proper role for the dominant social networks. Ivan Sigal
column28: the executive director of Global Voices
column29: an organization committed to using the internet to foster understanding across borders
column30: took to Twitter to observe in light of the Sri Lanka attacks that
column31: “A few years ago we’d be using these platforms to help each other and coordinating assistance. Now we view them as a threat.” He continued
column32: “A few years ago we’d view the blocking of social media sites after an attack as outrageous censorship; now we think of it as essential duty of care
column33: to protect ourselves from threat. #facebook your house is not in order.” In a more innocent era
column34: social networks were considered incredible communications tools—part phone
column36: part holiday letter—nothing but a boon for our increasingly disconnected lives. In times of crisis
column38: they would bind us even closer together. Soon enough
column39: we began to worry if this was the complete picture. We saw social networks as addictive and not necessarily so good for our own health and the health of children—that is
column40: something we clearly enjoyed using but maybe should figure out a way to reduce our dependence on
column41: either through will power or government regulation. A vice like casino gambling or tobacco. Now we are recognizing that there is an inherent potential for extremism lurking within global social networks that makes them a danger. There simply may be no safe way to deploy social networks during times of crisis or when bad actors include them in their anti-democratic playbooks. By automatically amplifying any and all messages that appear on their platforms and using highly personal data and algorithms to target those messages to where they will have the greatest potency
column42: social networks are weapons. They must be viewed not as an extension of the people who use them but as a danger to the greater society. We need social network control—sensible rules about where
column44: and what kinds of platforms should be free to operate
column45: much the way nearly all governments in the world impose comprehensive regulations about where
column47: and what kinds of guns should be allowed in communities. To fail to rein in social networks because of appeals to “freedom” would be like allowing vague words written 250 years ago to get in the way of controlling guns. I’ve come slowly and in fits and starts to this view. Until recently
column48: I’ve preferred to focus on the bad actors who misuse social networks—not only the hate peddlers but the Silicon Valley CEOs who profit from the networks’ misuse. These amoral leaders seemed the appropriate target of scorn. But by focusing on those individuals’ shortcomings
column49: wasn’t I buying into the argument that there was a good way for these social networks to operate
column50: even during a time of crisis or during divisive elections? If only they had the right leaders! In essence
column51: I was replicating the tired defense of unrestrained gun ownership—social networks don’t kill people
column52: people kill people. In point of fact
column53: guns magnify the violence of their users
column54: as do social networks. Reading the defenses mounted on behalf of social networks in response to Sri Lanka’s decision to impose the blackout (including on WIRED) again reminded me of the gun control debate. Some defenders noted that Sri Lanka has a relatively unfree press and that social networks were an important alternate source of news and reporting. Alp Toker
column56: a London-based organization that tracks internet bans around the world
column57: spoke to the Associated Press about the vacuum of information that is left in the wake of the Sri Lanka social network shutdown and is “readily exploited by other parties. It can add to the sense of fear and can cause panic.” This
column59: speaks to the potency of social networks—their defenders are promising that social networks can replace a corrupt system with a user-based one. I understand the attraction of such a claim
column60: even if it is a form of the gun extremist’s contention that the best answer to a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun. That is
column61: a defense based on seeing the status quo as irredeemably flawed
column62: and favoring a type of every-person-for-themself anarchy in its place. There were other arguments that quickly emerged online in defense of social networks. Some referred to a study that asserted that closing down social networks led to more violence. These assertions can be hard to assess. Opponents of gun laws will argue that the areas with the strictest gun laws—often large cities—have the most gun violence. So how effective is gun control then? Finally
column63: there was the popular defense that says
column64: Don’t judge us by the worst users but by our best users. That is
column65: guns give people a sense of security; they are used for hunting; shooting is a popular sport. A Facebook spokesperson emphasized how the platform served vital functions in a time of crisis. “People rely on our services to communicate with their loved ones and we are committed to maintaining our services and helping the community and the country during this tragic time
column66: ” the spokesperson said. The statement begins
column67: “Our hearts go out to the victims
column68: their families and the community affected by this horrendous act.” A worthwhile sentiment
column69: though it must be said that when such sentiments are expressed by gun control opponents after a mass shooting
column70: they are frequently mocked as merely “thoughts and prayers.” What we really need are thoughtful laws. Steve Stephens recorded himself murdering an innocent victim and then uploaded the footage to Facebook. The horrific act has put Facebook under immense pressure to do something
column71: but can the company prevent broadcasting acts of violence without fundamentally changing the purpose of the social media platform. WIRED explores Facebook's limited options. column1: ---split---5.0---split---https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/23/opinion/when-license-plate-surveillance-goes-horribly-wrong.html---split---Advertisement Supported by The pitfalls of automated policing
column2: where one piece of bad information can lead to a guns-drawn confrontation. By Charlie Warzel Mr. Warzel is an Opinion writer at large. This article is part of a limited-run newsletter. You can sign up here. Brian Hofer and his brother were on their way home from a Thanksgiving visit
column3: headed toward Oakland
column4: Calif.
column5: on Interstate 80 when he saw the flashing lights. Police officers directed him off the highway and into a shopping center. That’s around the time the guns came out. According to Mr. Hofer
column6: he was escorted out of his car and cuffed. From the back of a squad car
column7: he recalls watching officers
column8: guns drawn
column9: push his handcuffed brother to his knees. Hofer says the officers pointed a gun at the back of his brother’s head. “I was terrified
column10: ” Mr. Hofer told me. “I’m sitting ice-cold and saying nothing because I do not want any itchy trigger fingers.” After a few minutes
column11: officers told Mr. Hofer the car he’d been driving — a rental using the app Getaround — had been reported stolen earlier that year. From the back of the squad car
column12: Hofer attempted to explain the situation
column13: allowing police to use the Getaround app to find his paperwork and contact the company. After roughly 40 minutes
column14: police verified Hofer’s identity and he and his brother were released. So what happened? According to police
column15: Mr. Hofer’s car was flagged by a fixed stationary camera near the tiny city of Hercules
column16: Calif. The stationary camera
column17: operated by a company called Vigilant Solutions
column18: scanned the license plate of Mr. Hofer’s car
column19: which matched the number to a “hot list” registry of stolen vehicles. Within minutes Vigilant’s cameras pinged law enforcement — quickly enough that they were able to pull Mr. Hofer over just miles up the road. Mr. Hofer’s harrowing journey highlights the pitfalls of automated policing
column20: where one piece of bad information can lead to a guns-drawn confrontation. In one respect
column21: the system worked as intended: Mr. Hofer’s car had indeed previously been stolen. But because the “hot list” database of stolen vehicles hadn’t been properly updated to show the car was no longer stolen
column22: the license-plate scan triggered law enforcement. Detainments like Mr. Hofer’s are a growing reality for millions of Americans
column23: whose movements are being constantly tracked by an array of surveillance cameras
column24: some of which actively contact law enforcement. In California
column25: the cameras have resulted in a number of notable traffic stops of criminals
column26: in some cases leading police to murder and arson suspects. But according to an estimate from the Northern California Regional Intelligence Center
column27: the machines have a troubling 10 percent error rate. Mr. Hofer happens to be the chairman of Oakland’s Privacy Advisory Commission. In addition to filing a federal lawsuit against the Contra Costa County Sheriff’s Department for the detainment
column28: he’s speaking out against the surveillance technology. “The error rate of this technology is incredibly alarming
column29: ” he told me. “If one in 10 innocent people end up stopped with a gun pulled on them
column30: that is a lot of potential for abuse.” Despite his role as a privacy advocate
column31: Mr. Hofer isn’t afraid of technological innovation. His main concern is preserving the right to be anonymous in public. “If we allow law enforcement to rewind life and search through our every interaction
column32: our relationship to public life is forever altered
column33: ” he said. “And I simply don’t understand the idea that if we use enough technology
column34: we can achieve a zero percent crime rate. I reject that because that’s going to lead to extreme overpolicing.” Mr. Hofer hopes his lawsuit and continuing work will help slow the use of surveillance technology by showing how digital automated systems can have outsize impact in the physical realm. “They built a system to mitigate harm
column35: and yet I ended up with guns pulled on me due to faulty data
column36: ” he said. “And it’s more proof that we’ve built this invisible layer behind the scenes that leads to real-world consequences.” This week’s archive pick is a fascinating February 2001 article on the trend of big online companies creating corporate privacy officers roles. As with last week’s archive
column37: it’s a bit jarring to see how little things have changed in the privacy landscape over the past two decades. Take this description of the ad company DoubleClick: “DoubleClick
column38: which distributes ads to consumers on thousands of Web sites
column39: has taken a public beating from advocates for privacy rights
column40: who contend that it tracks people’s online wanderings too intrusively. The company has consistently denied that its policies violate consumer privacy; the Federal Trade Commission recently dropped an inquiry
column41: but it still faces class action suits and lawsuits by state attorneys general. And so DoubleClick is redoubling its efforts to build a reputation as a company that protects privacy.” In 2007
column43: which only further entrenched the tech giant’s position as the dominant player in online ads. There’s an undercurrent of hope running through the 2001 piece that the corporate world is turning a corner on online privacy
column44: which reads as a bit depressing in 2019. There’s even hints of excitement that legislators are looking into the online ad space — “This issue is exploding in Washington
column45: ” a person says in the piece. As we know now
column46: online ads never got that meaningful scrutiny. But no quote stood out as much as this hopeful passage from an I.T. professor: “Mary Culnan
column47: a professor of management and information technology at Bentley College in Waltham
column50: ’ and corporations have moved from a time of sensationalistic exposés of privacy flaws to trying to figure out how to use personal information responsibly and with customer consent. ‘It’s not the sort of land mine blowing up any more
column52: it’s a good reminder that we should probably always be wary of proclamations that “the game has changed.” We know that most websites and social media platforms constantly track us and share and store that information. And we also know that most of those companies offer the option to disable or “opt out” of data sharing and marketing services. But those preferences are often hard to find and buried deep in the bowels of obscure privacy pages. Thankfully
column55: created Simple Opt Out — a handy webpage that will help you disable these services for over 50 companies
column56: including major retailers but also companies like Facebook and 23&Me. Here’s how he described the genesis of the site to me: “I created it because I discovered that Crate & Barrel sells not only its customers’ information to third parties
column57: but also its customers’ purchase histories. Turns out that’s fairly common in the retail world. If you’ve used a retail point-of-sale system to buy something
column58: a retailer has probably sold/rented/traded your purchase — with your contact info — to a third party.” You’ll still have to log into the websites yourself and change the appropriate settings
column59: but the site is incredibly handy in that it organizes the links in one place. It’s a great way to take back a tiny bit of control or
column61: get a sense of what many companies are trying to siphon from you and your digital footprint. Your feedback will be a crucial part of the direction of this newsletter from week to week. You can send it here. And we’ll answer questions every week. Q: Do you have any advice for how to talk to friends and family about privacy? I know how to counter the “nothing to hide” argument with the following: “O.K.
column62: give me all your passwords then!” But past that
column63: it’s sometimes hard to explain the problems that giving up your data introduces. My friends will say they don’t care about Facebook having their data
column64: because they don’t know any employees at Facebook
column65: so they’re not worried about embarrassment. How can we make privacy more personal? It seems to me like we need to find ways to make the harms more tangible on an individual level
column66: but I don’t have enough examples in my back pocket. Would love any advice on how to have these more productive discussions. A: Making the digital privacy issue personal is a constant struggle. Here’s how one ad industry veteran put it to me: “People only care about privacy in the abstract — not in reality. I think it’s because often
column67: it’s either privacy or spending money. They don’t want to pay for most of the services online. They’d rather have this low-grade anxiety than spend money.” But as I argued last week
column68: I think that’s because people have a limited definition of privacy. It’s not just about data breaches or having access to their pictures or passwords. And one way to drive that point home to friends
column69: family or anyone else is to show them not only how much information is being captured but also how that information is being sliced and diced and used to make value judgments about a person. I’d point your family members to a piece like this
column70: where a woman looks at data collected about her and the categories they fall into: “My Mastercard UK shopping interests
column72: includes travel and leisure to Canada (I have in fact been to Canada recently for work) and frequent transactions in Bagel Restaurants (I can remember one night out where I’ve purchased quite a few bagels). Others are Experian UK classifies me according to my assumed financial situation (for some inexplicable reason I’m classified as “City Prosperity:World-Class Wealth”)
column73: the data broker Acxiom even placed me in a category called ‘Alcohol at Home Heavy Spenders.’” Maybe your family members are O.K. with that information being collected by financial companies and credit agencies. But are they fine with those customers trading that information with other companies (often this happens without our knowledge)? Our current data dystopia isn’t just about forking over information; it’s also about how that information moves across the web and how it leaks to both neutral and bad actors. This Wall Street Journal article on online trust score companies. These companies are a sobering example of the secondary layer of the internet that we can’t see and that is gobbling up our information and making decisions that affect our lives. The Financial Times has a deep dive on facial recognition and the reasons for concern. In sum: It’s not just that your face might be in a database; it’s how the databases can get shared and how the purpose of that monitoring changes over time in ways that might affect your privacy. Here’s a thought-provoking piece on late-model cars and how they’re constantly collecting data on the way we drive
column74: where we go and even personal information (weight
column76: etc.). This figure surprised me: “a car can generate about 25 gigabytes of data every hour and as much as 4
column78: according to some estimates.” Follow @privacyproject on Twitter and The New York Times Opinion Section on Facebook and Instagram. Charlie Warzel
